isis.stitle: TSI 95-13-02 - Spicer Range Shift Fork and Piston Rod Assembly Improvement

subjectgroup.subject: Spicer Range Shift Fork and Piston Rod Assembly Improvement

note.para: The information supplied herein has been furnished by the manufacturer and/or the supplier for use with its product. Navistar International Corp. reprints this information based on representations made to the Company by the manufacturer and/or supplier and is not responsible for any errors or untoward consequences resulting from such errors or from any misuse of the product. Every user is urged to carefully follow the instructions which accompany the product.

lev1.para: This TSI applies to all models with Spicer and Navistar 9 and 10 speed transmissions.

lev1.title: Wear Out Symptoms
lev1.para: Transmission will not shift into Low Range or jumps out of Low Range.
Transmission Low Range Output Gear clutch teeth worn excessively.

lev1.title: Possible Causes
lev1.para: Range Shift Fork has loosened on the range piston shift rod.
Range Shift Fork slots worn excessively.

lev1.title: What to Do
lev1.para: If the range shift fork hub is found not to be pressed flush against the piston rod shoulder as shown in Figure 1, replace with new Range Shift Fork, Rod & Roll Pin Assembly 201-66-23-2X.
If necessary, replace 313627X Range Synchronizer Assembly and 201-8-41 Low Range Output gear and any other parts that are damaged or worn excessively.

partsinfo.para: After 4-1-95 (Trans. Serial Number J950401001), the 201-66-23-2X Range Shift Fork Assembly was manufactured to retain the shift fork on the range piston rod using a press fit and a roll pin. The Range Shift Fork slots were made more robust by inserting clips in the fork slots. The range synchronizer collar, synchronizer races and low range output gear may become worn or damaged if the range fork loosens and is not pressed tight against the shoulder on the range piston rod. Due to varying degrees of damage and wear, the replacement of the range synchronizer collar and races and Low Range Output Gear is not always required.
